objenome.util

Enum BenchmarkSolutions

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<BenchmarkSolutions>
      • objenome.util.BenchmarkSolutions
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<BenchmarkSolutions>

    public enum BenchmarkSolutions
extends java.lang.Enum<BenchmarkSolutions>
    This class provides correct solutions to various benchmark problems that can be used within fitness functions
    Since:
    2.0

      • cubicRegression

        public static java.lang.Double cubicRegression(java.lang.Double x)
        Calculates and returns the correct result of the target function used in the cubic regression benchmark problem, for the given value of x. The target function of the cubic regression function is: x + x^2 + x^3
        Parameters:
        x - the input value
        Returns:
        the result of applying the function to the given value of x

      • quarticRegression

        public static java.lang.Double quarticRegression(java.lang.Double x)
        Calculates and returns the correct result of the target function used in the quartic regression benchmark problem, for the given value of x. The target function of the quartic regression function is: x + x^2 + x^3 + x^4
        Parameters:
        x - the input value
        Returns:
        the result of applying the function to the given value of x

      • sexticRegression

        public static java.lang.Double sexticRegression(java.lang.Double x)
        Calculates and returns the correct result of the target function used in the sextic regression benchmark problem, for the given value of x. The target function of the sextic regression function is: x^6 - (2 * x^4) + x^2
        Parameters:
        x - the input value
        Returns:
        the result of applying the function to the given value of x

      • multiplexer

        public static boolean multiplexer(java.lang.Boolean[] inputs)
        Calculates and returns the correct result of the multiplexer benchmark problem for the given input values. The first n elements of the input array are the address bits and the remaining m bits are the data bits. The following must be true: m = 2^m If this will be called multiple times, it is more efficient to obtain the number of address bits using multiplexerAddressBits(int) and pass them to the #multiplexer(boolean[], int) method.
        Parameters:
        inputs - an array of boolean inputs
        Returns:
        the result of applying a correct multiplexer on the given inputs

      • multiplexer

        public static boolean multiplexer(java.lang.Boolean[] inputs,
                                  int noAddressBits)
        Calculates and returns the correct result of the multiplexer benchmark problem for the given input values and the number of address bits. The first n elements of the input array are the address bits and the remaining m bits are the data bits. The following must be true: m = 2^m
        Parameters:
        inputs - an array of boolean inputs
        noAddressBits - the number of address bits to expect in the inputs array
        Returns:
        the result of applying a correct multiplexer on the given inputs

      • multiplexerAddressBits

        public static int multiplexerAddressBits(int noBits)
        Calculates and returns the number of address bits are required for a given number of input bits when solving the multiplexer problem.
        Parameters:
        noBits - the total number of input bits, including both address and data bits
        Returns:
        the number of address bits
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the number of data bits is invalid, given the number of address bits

      • majority

        public static java.lang.Boolean majority(java.lang.Boolean[] inputs)
        Calculates and returns the correct result of the majority benchmark problem for the given input values.
        Parameters:
        inputs - an array of boolean inputs
        Returns:
        the result of applying majority on the given input values

      • evenParity

        public static java.lang.Boolean evenParity(java.lang.Boolean[] inputs)
        Calculates and returns the correct result of checking for even parity in the given input values.
        Parameters:
        inputs - an array of boolean inputs
        Returns:
        true if there is an even number of true values in the input array

      • oddParity

        public static java.lang.Boolean oddParity(java.lang.Boolean[] inputs)
        Calculates and returns the correct result of checking for odd parity in the given input values.
        Parameters:
        inputs - an array of boolean inputs
        Returns:
        true if there is an odd number of true values in the input array

      • generateBoolSequences

        public static java.lang.Boolean[][] generateBoolSequences(int noBits)
        Generates an array of Boolean arrays of all possible combinations of true/false values for the given number of elements.

        This function will not cope with large values of noBits over about 30 due to size limitations of the int datatype, and maximum array sizes. There are also likely to be issues with heap space. It is recommended in most cases to use the alternative BooleanUtils.generateBoolSequence(int, long) method which generates the same boolean arrays on an individual basis.

        Parameters:
        noBits - the number of boolean values in which different combinations are made
        Returns:
        an array of all the possible boolean arrays possible with the given number of elements. There will be 2noBits combinations and so the returned array will have this many elements.
